awd_titl_txt: D3SC: Integrated Studies on Designing Organometallic Complexes with Nonlinear Absorption and Near-Infrared Emission
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Bakhtiyor Rasulev, Dmitri S Kilin, Svetlana V Kilina, and Wenfang Sun at North Dakota State University are developing new organometallic complexes with nonlinear optical absorption (NLO) and near IR (NIR) emission properties.  The approach involves the application of combined computational and data-driven methods.  The new methodology could offer an efficient and cost-effective development of optical materials for various applications.  These applications include optical communication, data storage, dynamic holography, optical switching, optical limiting, photodynamic therapy, and/or photocatalysis.  The project lies at the interface of organic, inorganic, materials chemistry, theoretical quantum chemistry, cheminformatics and data mining approaches, and is therefore well suited to the education of scientists at all levels. This group is also well positioned to provide the highest level of education and training for students underrepresented in science. Outreach activities involving tribal college students and K-12 students will also be part of the funded project.  

Transition metal complexes display a rich array of photophysical properties where substituted ligands can be used both for the tuning of excited states and as conduits for electron- and energy-transfer.   In this project, the combination of experimental, computational, cheminformatics and data mining methods are being used to reveal the factors responsible for NLO properties and near IR emission properties.  A broad library of organometallic complexes that possess specific optical properties, by in-house data, as well as a large set of data collected from various public sources using computer science methods, will be studied.   A virtual library of thousands of promising organometallic complexes will be generated and the most promising ones will be synthesized and tested, to confirm the data-driven findings.  It is hoped that new complexes will be achieved with the following desirable properties: (1) weak and broad absorption at visible to NIR region, (2) intense excited state absorption to guaranty a large ratio of the excited-state absorption cross section relative to that of the ground-state absorption, (3) long-lived triplet excited states, and (4) relatively high triplet quantum yield.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
A new methodology for rational design of organometallic materials in the field of dye-sensitized solar cells, catalysis, sensing, displays, optical limiting, and bio-imaging is in high demand. Discovery of new near-IR absorbing and emissive materials is critical for applications in fluorescent biomarkers, photodynamic therapy, fluorescent sensors, photovoltaics, and light emitting diodes (LEDs). 

Research Outcome: This project is investigated nonlinear optical absorption (NLA) and near-IR (NIR) emission properties of transition-metal complexes (TMCs) and established a quantitative structure-property relationship that allowing a chemical control and tuning of NIR and NLA properties in these materials. For this, a procedure for property characterizations and design cycle for these complex molecular systems was developed by application of combined approach of computational and data-driven methods and experimental investigations. 

The project's findings provide important insights into the effect of chemical structure of ligands and metal centers in complexes on its optical response and complement worldwide efforts in improving optical performance of the metal-organic complexes at the NIR range via rational chemical design. In particular, our joined experimental and computational research directly assists in novel design strategies for creating new materials with improved NIR emission and reverse saturable absorption (RSA). Additionally, the developed computational and data driven methods provide a guidance for synthesis and inspire new experimental probes focused on NLA and NIR materials. The new methodology can be applied for other organometallic materials as well, to improve their properties of interest.

Performed study lies at the forefront of research including soft, electronically functional matter, luminescent organics, photochemistry, quantum technology, sensors, energy storage and conversion, which are currently of great interest for NSF-related missions.

In addition, the developed new interdisciplinary machine learning-based cheminformatics methodology to design organometallic materials can boost the development of artificial intelligence (AI) techniques for development of other various hybrid materials and nanomaterials.

Broader Impact: The project resulted in the training of 10 students 7 PhD  and 3 undergraduates, one postdoctoral researcher, the publication of 20 scientific articles in high-impact journals, as well as a number of presentations to scientific conferences and symposiums. This project provided interdisciplinary training opportunity to both undergraduate and graduate students on quantum chemistry, machine learning, and cheminformatics techniques, as well as on simulations of materials’ properties and method development. Student also trained to have better skills in scientific writing and presentations. All these activities prepared future working forces for research in materials science. Thus, our research helped to attract new students to the STEM programs at NDSU and inspired the innovative capacity of a new generation of American scientists. All PIs are actively participated in several outreach activities organized for high school students interested in STEM disciplines. This helped to build human related infrastructure on institutional level, since these activities are attracting a lot of potential new students to NDSU, which brings additional funding from ND State. The project facilitated various other outreach activities, such as the Welcome Days and other workshops mentioned above, public presentations, editing books, organizing conferences, participation at the conferences and participation in the NATURE Program, PICNICS program, all of which are intended to advance STEM fields literacy of the general public and young students.

The PI and co-PIs are actively used the available computational resources at NDSU and moreover, contributed with a new NSF MRI grant funding to acquire a new supercomputer for $1.2M from NSF (received in 2020 the NSF Major Infrastructure Instrument award, NSF MRI-2019077).


Last Modified: 11/30/2022
Modified by: Bakhtiyor Rasulev
